title: Monday, 14th March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Now

PM

Found myself drawn to drugs this morning

11:01 am
PM

John Hempton started it

PM

PM

http://brontecapit...ness.html?spref=tw

11:02 am
PM

The LA Times explores Valeant's business model
The LA Times has a savage little article on herpes (or cold sore) topical medication. In Australia you can buy small tubes of Zovirax topical medication for about $15 over the counter.

In America it is somewhat more complicated - and an insurance company winds up paying about $2500.

PM

Now, as a reader was quick to point out that LA Times thing is a year old

PM

http://www.latimes...150306-column.html

11:03 am
PM

But it reminded me of when I lived in NY and one of my daughters came back from the doctors with some acne cream.

PM

It cost $400.

PM

But that LA Times piece took me here: http://www.goodrx.com/

11:04 am
PM

Site you can check US drug prices

PM

Which took me here....

PM

11:05 am
PM

Bensal is one of Valeant's top selling drugs

PM

Its for all sorts of dermatitis

PM

But you know what, you can buy that stuff in the UK for less than £4

11:05 am
PM

Not $800

PM

It's four quid

PM

11:06 am
PM

That's the same stuff -- Whitfield's ointment

PM

The active ingredient was discovered by Nostradamus

PM

In circa 1556

11:07 am
PM

And now Valeant are selling a version of it for $800

PM

Why doesn't America wake up to this?

PM

Total Madness

11:08 am
PM

Valeant may have already fallen a long way

PM

But it still has another circa $68 to fall

undefined
11:08 am
PM

Sorry about that Bryce

PM

Had to share

BE

No problem -- it gave me time to go through the GW Pharma press release that dropped immediately as we arrived on air.

11:09 am
GW Pharmaceuticals PLC (GWP:LSE): Last: 224.56, up 8.06 (+3.72%), High: 227.50, Low: 218.75, Volume: 186.59k

BE

http://www.investe...1603141100029771R/

11:10 am
PM

This is the epilepsy test?

BE

Yup, and the data look pretty good. Surprisingly so, perhaps.

BE

patients taking Epidiolex achieved a median reduction in monthly convulsive seizures of 39 percent compared with a reduction on placebo of 13 percent

11:10 am
PM

Impressive

BE

You'll remember that placebo rates are extremely high for tests on children

BE

Possibly because the reporting of results has to go through the filter of their parents

11:11 am
BE

Who've read all the press and really want the medicine to work.

BE

Anyway, the concern here was that given the high placebo rate the trial would be too small to deliver a p=0.01.

BE

That seems not to be the case, on my cursory reading, and that makes the 37% rally in response feel a little mean.

11:13 am
PM

If this does work for 40% of kids it's very good news for those with severe epilepsy. Friend of my wife's has a affected kid

PM

They have to be within 10 yards of her 24 hours a day

BE

Yup, though this is for one very rare strain of epilepsy, Dravet.

11:15 am
BE

Which was picked because there's a bit of a race to market at the moment to get the next generation of epilepsy treatments approved.

PM

incidence rate of 1:16,000 to 1:21,000

BE

The lack of an effective treatment currently means Epidiolex is getting a fast-track FDA process -- though always remember that the FDA don't approve stuff based on a press release.

11:16 am
BE

There we go, though. 64% now.

BE

Told you 30% looked a bit mean.

undefined

So the market generally still enjoying this warm ECB bath

FTSE ahead 0.6%, up 34 points at 6174

What there is is weak. Effect of yuan strength on exports etc, none of which is today news.

PM

You exaggerate, but still

11:23 am

And that £2.3bn is market cap. EV's about a zillion.

BE

Anyway, Barclays says "hold your breath and ....."

BE

Stock Rating OVERWEIGHT

11:24 am
BE

Building copper mines in emerging markets is a risky business, but we believe FQM’s
countercyclical investment to develop Cobre Panama has been the right one.
However, when it starts to threaten the balance sheet, the risks outweigh the benefits,
in our view. Management has announced a number of pro-active steps to ensure
profitability and cash flow of the business are maximized (including sale of Kevitsa for
$712m), and we believe there are further options to strengthen the balance sheet
sufficiently to offset these risks. While it is understandable that the current copper
price environment could continue to put pressure on the shares in the near term,
ultimately, the longer term investment case remains compelling with a 5yr CAGR in Cu
eq output of 17% and P/NPV of 0.7x. Retain OW; raise PT by 62% to 430p.

PM

(WIWY -- up 1.6%)

BE

Feedback from Zambia and Cobre Panama site visits: Having visited all 3 core assets in
the last 5 weeks, we provide some feedback in this note. We were particularly impressed
by Kansanshi’s solid cost-cutting and believe there is more to come. At Sentinel,
throughput is ramping up better than expected, but recoveries are still a work-inprogress,
in our view, and the timing of energizing of the second power line is a key risk to
Sentinel’s performance this year. Meanwhile, Cobre Panama is happing. If copper prices
dictate it, management could slow activity in 2017 (not 2016). Project financing is actively
under consideration, which could help ease liquidity pressures in 2018/19.
More balance sheet liquidity required by 2018 (or waiver of term loan amortization):
With the $1.2bn term loan starting to amortise from September ($200m payment every 6
months), the liquidity profile looks pretty tricky by 2018 even on spot prices today. Project
financing at Cobre would be a big liquidity boost, but if prices fall below 190c/lb over this
period even more action would be required by management post 2018. Management has
a number of options at its disposal, but we fear management’s positive outlook on copper
prices might delay such decisions until we actually sees lower commodity prices.
Reasonable relative valuation; still best-in-class NPV growth: The share price is trading
on reasonable near-term EBITDA multiples compared with peers, such as ANTO and KAZ
(12.5x vs 34-40x). Given FQM’s leverage, this improves significantly on spot (9.2x and
7.7x for 2016/17 vs 12-19x and 10x for ANTO and KAZ). On P/NPV, the shares look
compelling at 0.7x and with a 5yr CAGR in Cu eq output of 17% and P/NPV of only 0.46x
by 2020 using LT copper price of $2.75/lb.

11:24 am
BE

(@beakerandbunsen: 682m shares in issue, ~99% free float.)

Just reading round this ECB stuff, which continues to clog up my inbox -- I notice that Japan are now expected to move!

PM

PM

11:26 am
PM

PM

Here's some UBS

PM

Daiju Aoki

11:26 am
PM

BoJ to ease in March or April
We expect the BoJ to ease policy further either on 15 March or 28 April, an event to
which we attach a 65% probability. Driving this would be recent JPY strength (USDJPY
is well below corporate expectations), declining corporate sentiment, and downward
pressure on prices and inflation expectations. In addition, we think that Japanese
authorities will likely want to be seen to be active in averting a global recession ahead
of hosting the G7 on 26-27 May, particularly if other countries are providing monetary
and/or fiscal support for their economies.

PM

BoJ to increase QQE purchases by ¥20tn a year to ¥100tn

PM

omg smile

11:26 am
PM

We expect an increase of purchases in the BoJ’s Quantitative and Qualitative Easing
programme (QQE) by ¥20tn a year to ¥100tn. We see the BoJ with 3 other choices: cut
the policy IOER once more, a combination of a cut with some increased QQE and no
easing at all. In the medium term, however, we expect the options for BoJ easing to
revolve around lowering the interest rate on excess reserves (IOER).

PM

How would markets react to the new BoJ policy?
On an announcement of a QQE increase, we would expect a strong move upward in
USDJPY. In the rates markets, bull flattening of the yield curve would initially seem
likely, particularly in long maturities – though this could be reversed by increased
inflation expectations. For equities, we would expect a 5% upward move in TOPIX with
manufacturing, financial and real estate stocks outperforming other sectors.
What’s priced in?
A deposit rate cut of about 9bp but little increase in QQE purchases appears priced in
when assessing the March and April meetings together. Economist surveys suggest a
majority expects no easing at these meetings.
How would markets react to other BoJ policy outcomes?
If the BoJ did not move at all at either meeting, we would likely revisit our USDJPY
views to reflect less upside going forward. Yields would likely rise across rates curves –
with bear steepening in the long end - and equity prices would likely fall, led by export
and consumer sectors. We provide a flow diagram to show the market moves that we
would expect in each of the more probable BoJ policy outcomes.

PM

Yen$ at 113

InterContinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG:LSE): Last: 2,833, up 107 (+3.93%), High: 2,840, Low: 2,730, Volume: 517.49k

BE

As in, Hyatt or Marriott or whoever. It's notable that investors really don't seem to have welcomed the in-market consolidation among the hotel operators over the past year or so.

BE

However, once you can attach "Chinese" to any bid story it can run pretty much indefinitely.

11:35 am

Might Anbang buy IHG? Well, it's trying to buy everything else, so why not.

Having said that, of course, one would expect if InterContinental felt genuinely threatened right now it would've saved some cash back from its recent special divi to do a takeover defence.

BE

Which is what it did when Wyndham was sniffing around a year or two ago.

Established in 1999 following a management buyout from Logica plc, Cerillion develops, installs and supports billing, charging and customer relationship management ("CRM") solutions, predominantly to the telecommunications market. The business has a global customer base, across 40 countries and its customers include Cable & Wireless, KDDI and MTN.

PM

SELL
Target price 450p | Published price 874p

A major US college bookstore business reported Q3 numbers last week and indicated it was seeing a number of structural headwinds in the sales of textbooks and materials in the US higher education market. This seems at odds with Pearson’s comments about “cyclical / policy” factors being the main reason for the problems it faces in its US higher education side, which we estimate is at least one-third of group profits. Reiterate as top Sell.

11:55 am
PM

Barnes and Noble Education Q3 results

Barnes and Noble Education – which operates 743 US college bookstores – reported Q3 results last week. Q3 comparable sales fell 4.1% for the quarter, with textbook sales down 5.4% (including the first three weeks of February, comparable sales fell 2.9% and down 1.2% ex-community colleges). The company blamed the declines on later starts by many US colleges but also declines in US community college enrolments (25% of sales) and structural headwinds in their textbook sales business.

PM

B&N Education suggesting more structural factors impacting the materials business than Pearson suggests

PM

B&N Education noted that, ex-community colleges, the spring rush period was showing flat enrolments, However, their commentary on what was impacting textbook sales emphasises a number of structural factors impacting textbook sales, including students’ reluctance to buy textbooks and open education resources:

“As we look at sales for the quarter by merchandise category, our textbook sales declined 5.4% on a comparable basis, primarily due to the later Rush period and decreased enrollments in community colleges. Aggressive online marketplace pricing, digital direct courseware sales, OER (Open Education Resources) content, along with students’ reluctance to purchase textbooks, is providing some headwinds for course material sales. In order to combat these headwinds, we have successfully piloted our textbook price-matching program on multiple campuses this fall, and again during the Spring Rush.” (B&N Education 3Q
